original_data.question: A previously healthy 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain during exercise for the last 6 months. She does not smoke. Her maternal uncle had similar symptoms. Cardiac examination shows wide splitting of S2. The second component of S2 is loud and best heard at the 2nd left intercostal space. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's cardiac findings?

model_response:
The patient has a wide fixed split of S2, which is characteristic of an atrial septal defect (ASD). The right ventricular volume overload produced by the left-to-right shunt of blood results in an increase in right ventricular preload. The increased volume of blood in the right ventricle produces an increase in right ventricular stroke volume and a wide pulse pressure (difference between systolic and diastolic pressure). The left ventricular volume overload that occurs in ASD does not result in an increase in left ventricular preload because the shunt of blood occurs after the mitral valve has closed. The left ventricle does, however, have an increase in stroke volume because it pumps blood that it receives from the right ventricle through the left-to-right shunt. The left ventricular afterload is not affected by the presence of an ASD.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Height greater than two standard deviations below the mean of the appropriate reference population for the age and sex of the individual.
The air that is inhaled and exhaled during respiration.
The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.
Pressure, burning, or numbness in the chest.

Physical activity which is usually regular and done with the intention of improving or maintaining PHYSICAL FITNESS or HEALTH. Contrast with PHYSICAL EXERTION which is concerned largely with the physiologic and metabolic response to energy expenditure.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Visible gaseous suspension of carbon and other particulate matter emitted from burning substances.
A physical examination focusing on areas of interest other than the heart.
sound intensity; the relative extent to which a sound can be heard.
A condition in which a person partially loses the ability to hear sounds in one or both ears.
Space of compartment of trunk bounded by the upper and lower surfaces of two consecutive ribs.
Either of the pair of organs occupying the cavity of the thorax that effect the aeration of the blood.
Act of listening for sounds within the body.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
A clinical finding in which humming vibration; accompanying a loud, harsh or rumbling murmur felt during palpation of the precordium or over the blood vessels. (ACC-AHA)
